repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Economic Recovery Credit, Public
            Sector Adjustment Credit, Public Finance Reform Credit, and
            Public Finance Recovery Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome for the Economic
            Recovery Credit Project is rated as unsatisfactory; project
            sustainability is highly unlikely becaue of lack of
            ownership at the political and administrative levels and
            very weak resilience to exogenous factors. Bank performance
            is rated unsatisfactory because the Bank misjudged the depth
            of the political crisis, wrongly interpreted the
            Government's declaration for reforms as true
            commitment, and overlooked the lack of commitment within the
            administration. Borrower performance is rated highly
            unsatisfactory. The outcome of the Public Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project is rated moderately satisfactory and project
            sustainability is unlikely because there was not enough time
            before the April 1999 coup to fully internalize improvements
            in a sustainable manner. Bank and Borrower performance is
            rated satisfactory. The ratings for the Public Finance
            Reform Credit are satisfactory outcome, satisfactory Bank
            performance, and unsatisfactory Borrower performance.
            Sustainability is highly unlikely because of the objectives
            that were achieved, in the case of the civil service reform,
            some positive measures taken under the PSAC were reversed,
            For the Public Finance Recovery Credit, the original ratings
            of satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and
            satisfacotry performance for both the Bank and the Borrower
            are confirmed. The main lessons are: 1) Except for the
            obvious sine qua non condition of political stability,
            Government commitment is insufficient to ensure
            success--support within the administration and better
            communication between the Government and civil society are
            also necessary. 2) In countries with a large informal sector
            and a low tax base, the Bank and the International Monetary
            Fund should explore ways to adapt taxation to the
            particularities of the country, for instance through modest
            taxation of the agricultural sector. 3) Addressing the
            problem of very weak institutional capacity cannot be
            limited to a piecemeal approach via different operations but
            requires a full-fledged medium-term strategy agreed with the
            authorities, targeted at least at the central ministries,
            and combined with a monitoring and evaluation system in the
            country. 4) In countries having very limited resources,
            devaluation unaccompanied by longer-term investment and
            institutional support of the few existing productive sectors
            is unlikely to generate a lasting supply response, even if
            macroeconomic policies are sound, 5) Adjustment operations
            must include a domestic monitoring and evaluation mechanism
            to enable senior officials to assess progress and initiate
            corrective actions. 6) Single tranche operations justified
            by the contention that future lending will depend on
            continued performance do not guarantee good performance.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Public Finance Recovery Credit
            Project and Supplemental Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Finance Recovery
            Credit's outcome is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as modest, Bank performance as satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance as satisfactory. The main exogenous factor which
            affected the implementation and therefore the outcome of
            this operation is the shortage of external financing during
            the period of 2002 and 2001, which resulted in episodes of
            cash rationing and diverted attention away from structural
            reform implementation. On the one hand, the medium-term
            policy framework supported by such operations need to be as
            comprehensive as possible. On the other hand, evaluation of
            past adjustment operations for Niger and other countries has
            shown that an abundance of conditionalities have been a
            cause of unsatisfactory outcomes. The lesson learned is that
            in an emergency or recovery environment, adjustment support
            should be anchored in a medium-term framework. There may be
            occasions where the Bank must take calculated risk in
            providing a timely response to client need, but this can
            only occur on the basis of close work with the IMF
            beforehand and with Fund endorsement. Even when time does
            not permit the formulation of a parallel TA operation, there
            is potential for capacity building activities through the
            client's commitment of some of his own resources to
            that purpose, even if only to jump start activities in
            anticipation of subsequent external support.

repnme.cdata!: Niger - Public Finance Recovery Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Finance Recovery Credit
            Project for Niger is a single-tranche operation which will
            help sustain the government's financial stabilization
            and fiscal management effort and compensate for the tariff
            revenue shortfall caused by the implementation of the trade
            liberalization program of the West Africa Economic and
            Monetary Union (WAEMU). The credit falls within the
            framework of the government's medium-term development
            program aimed at stimulating economic growth and reducing
            poverty through 1) macroeconomic and fiscal stabilization,
            and 2) structural and sector-wide reforms mainly focusing on
            improving the delivery of social services delivery, trade
            promotion and formal private private sector activity, and
            the development of the rural economy. Successful
            implementation of the reform program and of the upcoming
            Poverty Reduction Growth Facility should provide substantial
            benefits in terms of macroeconomic and financial
            stabilization, and the efficiency of fiscal management. The
            credit assists the Government to further reinforce its
            credibility and that of the reform program, as well as
            facilitate consensus building around the proposed measures.
            Although the project is at high risk due to political and
            social instability, the incapacity to mobilize external
            resources, the realization of a low-case macroeconomic
            scenario, and weak implementation capacity, the
            credit's potential benefits are expected to outweigh
            these risks.
